data.title: Error installing Atom on Fedora 20 64b

I'm trying to install Atom on Fedora and when executing `script/build`, here's the error :

data.title: Add support esprima
data.body: ECMAScript parsing infrastructure for multipurpose analysis(http://esprima.org)

data.title: UNIX/Mac or Windows text format option for line endings
data.body: Developing on windows machine for running on linux machines doesnt work without running through a converter. Could there be an option to switch between the different kind of formats? I'm running a Windows build of Atom v.107 and it defaults to Windows line endings when editing.

data.title: The changes that by mmap can NOT be detected.
Error when double-clicking a word
data.body:
I recently switched to the React editor, and triggered an error double clicking a word (a Ruby instance variable, if it makes any difference).

It's reproducible: double clicking again on the word triggers another error in the console, even after closing and reopening the window or restarting the app.

Here is the stack trace:


(is there a better way to export that to something more readable than copying from the dev tools console?)

Here is a screen shot:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/44385/3477535/691fbe12-031d-11e4-9617-793300d7606f.png)

This was found in version 0.107.0, but I can reproduce it in 0.108.0, too.

data.title: Update the decoration API
data.body:
Starting this PR super early. I want to layout what I am thinking before getting into it. 
### Editor / DisplayBuffer

The API is designed to be consistent with the marker API. The marker API has a `markBufferRange` function that returns a `Marker` object. Removal of the marker is done through a `destroy` method. The Decorations API takes on the same form:
- `(Decoration) decorateMarker(marker, decorationParams)`

These remain unchanged:
- `(Decoration) decorationForId(decorationId)`
- `(Object) decorationsForScreenRowRange(startScreenRow, endScreenRow)`
### Decoration

New:
- `(void) destroy()` - this just calls `displayBuffer::removeDecoration(this)`
- `(void) update(newParams)` - update the params with newParams. Lets the `displayBuffer` know there was an update, which will notify the `EditorComponent`.

Unchanged:
- `flash`
### TODO
- [x] `Decoration::destroy()` 
- [x] `Decoration::update()` 
- [x] `DisplayBuffer / Editor::decorateMarker()` 
- [x] Update packages using decorations

data.title: Concept of multiple projects alive (but not active)
data.body:
``` coffee
# Empty workspace
atom.projects.push {"name": "x", "path": "...."}
atom.projects.activate "x"

# project "x" is now active in the tree view 
# and its "state" (open documents, etc.) is being stored

atom.projects.push {"name": "y", "path": "...."}
atom.projects.activate "y"

# project "y" is now active in the tree view but the 
# state of "x" was not lost

atom.projects.activate "x"

# switch back to project "x" exactly as you've left it
```

Something like that (of course the API could be something else). This would allow for something like https://atom.io/packages/project-manager to be able to switch projects seamlessly in the same window.

If we can agree on the API I'll take a crack at implementing (unless someone already has this under way and I didn't notice the issue).

data.title: Not autoscrolling to cursor on deleting text
data.body:
Start with a file that is several screens long.  Select from the top but leave enough text to still have more than 1 full page worth.  Delete the selection.  The cursor is at the proper location, at the top of the now deleted section, but the cursor is not scrolled into view.

![test](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/997659/3476457/06ba64d8-0300-11e4-8e38-3f7a419c9aef.gif)

data.title: Remove fnr marker less from themes, and into fnr
Not autoscrolling when cursor moves due to undo
bufferRangeForScopeAtCursor() returns only range from one line
data.body:
Having a coffee script

``` coffee
   foo = ///
      first line
      second line
      ///
```

if cursor is on "first line", editor's getBufferRangeForScopeAtCursor() returns only range for "      first line", not for "\n     first line\n      second line\n    " as I expected.

data.title: Codesign on Windows CI
data.body: Closes #1034

data.title: Multiple selection buggy with React editor
data.body:
Using Atom v0.106.0 on Mac OS X 10.8.5

To change a variable name I often use the combination of `Cmd + double-click` to select multiple occurrences of a word. That doesn't seem to work with the React editor turned on (but works fine with React turned off). I can still do `Cmd + click-and-drag` though.

Placing multiple cursors with just `Cmd + click` does seem to work with the React editor on, but it's a bit buggy: as soon as I have a certain number of cursors placed (say more than 7), some of the code disappears and I still see the cursors blinking.

Pics below.

Let me know if there is any other information I can provide to help.

Thanks!

Trying to select the first 3 three `datetimeUtils` with `Cmd + double-click`: the first ones highlight but the other ones I only get a cursor
![screen shot 2014-07-03 at 11 04 37 am](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1306536/3471595/204cd4bc-02c4-11e4-8941-f800f3d8e5fc.png)

Expected behavior is still possible by using `Cmd + click-and-drag`:
![screen shot 2014-07-03 at 11 05 02 am](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1306536/3471607/508ea5ba-02c4-11e4-9af6-07f1866190c5.png)

Placing too many cursors with `Cmd + click`: code disappears. I have to close the file and open it again.
![screen shot 2014-07-03 at 11 05 48 am](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1306536/3471622/747e7112-02c4-11e4-8db7-0fb5a5c03467.png)

This is what the file looks like when freshly opened:
![screen shot 2014-07-03 at 11 07 44 am](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1306536/3471626/7a6cd834-02c4-11e4-8599-a105aff57d49.png)

data.title: Canceling multiple matching (cmd-D) doesn't reset cursor position
data.body:
For example, given the text

```
a a a a
^ caret here
```

If you hit `cmd-D` four times you will select all four `a`s. But then hitting `esc` (mapped to "single selection") you end up with:

```
a a a a
      ^ caret
```

data.title: File open in two panes affected by text selection
data.body:
Hi,

I'm not sure if this is perhaps intended or not, figured it's worth a mention.
1. Open a file in two panes.
2. Select some text in the first pane.
3. Make some edits in the second.
4. Watch as the selection in the first pane is replaced by the edits from the second, regardless of the cursors position in the second page.

Doesn't always happen immediately. Sorry for the low quality below.

![Example](http://i.minus.com/ibllhhm6X8AC80.gif)

data.title: Build on Windows 8.1 with msysgit
data.body:
More detailed documentation on how to build on windows 8.1 with msysgit. One issue I've found with this is that the package manager doesn't download packages right because of git not being on the path. I'll update as I figure it out.

If anyone knows how to specify the location of git binaries without having it on the path, please let me know.

data.title: Add support for inline editors.
data.body:
Brackets (based on CodeMirror) provide an interface for inline editors so the plugins can provide specialized editors for colors and such or even to provide a way to edit another file without opening it.

Currently Atom plugins need to either open a popup (e.g. different color pickers) or use a panel (e.g. Regex railroad graph plugin).

data.title: Fix jitter in React editor
data.body:
Fixes #2797
Refs #2769

I previously thought that using `setImmediate` instead of `nextTick` fixed our jitter issues when requesting updates from animation frames, but it seems I was wrong. This PR returns to a strategy of updating synchronously in animation frames, so we never mix calls to `requestAnimationFrame` with `setImmediate`.

This PR also fixes an issue where we would handle stale `scroll` events emitted by the scrollbar elements while we were in the middle of updates, which was another source of jitter. Now we no longer get this kind of unintentional feedback when setting the scroll position in the model.

@Flannelhead: Could you try this out when it lands to see if it addresses #2769 on Linux?

data.title: Language Coffee broken styling from RegEx
data.body:
I have a RegEx for TLDs first thing in a coffeescript file that breaks the color styling for the rest of the file.

```
/^(http(?:s?)\:\/\/|~\/|\/)?(?:\w+:\w+@)?([A-Za-z0-9-]{1,63}\.)+(COMMUNITY|DIRECTORY|EDUCATION|EQUIPMENT|INSTITUTE|MARKETING|SOLUTIONS|XN--J1AMH|XN--L1ACC|BARGAINS|BOUTIQUE|BUILDERS|CATERING|CLEANING|CLOTHING|COMPUTER|DEMOCRAT|DIAMONDS|GRAPHICS|HOLDINGS|LIGHTING|PARTNERS|PLUMBING|TRAINING|VENTURES|XN--P1AI|ACADEMY|CAREERS|COMPANY|CRUISES|DOMAINS|EXPOSED|FLIGHTS|FLORIST|GALLERY|GUITARS|HOLIDAY|KITCHEN|RECIPES|RENTALS|REVIEWS|SHIKSHA|SINGLES|SUPPORT|SYSTEMS|AGENCY|BERLIN|CAMERA|CENTER|COFFEE|CONDOS|DATING|ESTATE|EVENTS|EXPERT|FUTBOL|KAUFEN|LUXURY|MAISON|MONASH|MUSEUM|NAGOYA|PHOTOS|REPAIR|REPORT|SOCIAL|TATTOO|TIENDA|TRAVEL|VIAJES|VILLAS|VISION|VOTING|VOYAGE|BUILD|CARDS|CHEAP|CODES|DANCE|EMAIL|GLASS|HOUSE|NINJA|PARTS|PHOTO|SHOES|SOLAR|TODAY|TOKYO|TOOLS|WATCH|WORKS|AERO|ARPA|ASIA|BIKE|BLUE|BUZZ|CAMP|CLUB|COOL|COOP|FARM|GIFT|GURU|INFO|JOBS|KIWI|LAND|LIMO|LINK|MENU|MOBI|MODA|NAME|PICS|PINK|POST|QPON|RICH|RUHR|SEXY|TIPS|WANG|WIEN|ZONE|BIZ|CAB|CAT|CEO|COM|EDU|GOV|INT|KIM|MIL|NET|ONL|ORG|PRO|RED|TEL|UNO|WED|XXX|AC|AD|AE|AF|AG|AI|AL|AM|AN|AO|AQ|AR|AS|AT|AU|AW|AX|AZ|BA|BB|BD|BE|BF|BG|BH|BI|BJ|BM|BN|BO|BR|BS|BT|BV|BW|BY|BZ|CA|CC|CD|CF|CG|CH|CI|CK|CL|CM|CN|CO|CR|CU|CV|CW|CX|CY|CZ|DE|DJ|DK|DM|DO|DZ|EC|EE|EG|ER|ES|ET|EU|FI|FJ|FK|FM|FO|FR|GA|GB|GD|GE|GF|GG|GH|GI|GL|GM|GN|GP|GQ|GR|GS|GT|GU|GW|GY|HK|HM|HN|HR|HT|HU|ID|IE|IL|IM|IN|IO|IQ|IR|IS|IT|JE|JM|JO|JP|KE|KG|KH|KI|KM|KN|KP|KR|KW|KY|KZ|LA|LB|LC|LI|LK|LR|LS|LT|LU|LV|LY|MA|MC|MD|ME|MG|MH|MK|ML|MM|MN|MO|MP|MQ|MR|MS|MT|MU|MV|MW|MX|MY|MZ|NA|NC|NE|NF|NG|NI|NL|NO|NP|NR|NU|NZ|OM|PA|PE|PF|PG|PH|PK|PL|PM|PN|PR|PS|PT|PW|PY|QA|RE|RO|RS|RU|RW|SA|SB|SC|SD|SE|SG|SH|SI|SJ|SK|SL|SM|SN|SO|SR|ST|SU|SV|SX|SY|SZ|TC|TD|TF|TrG|TH|TJ|TK|TL|TM|TN|TO|TP|TR|TT|TV|TW|TZ|UA|UG|UK|US|UY|UZ|VA|VC|VE|VG|VI|VN|VU|WF|WS|YE|YT|ZA|ZM|ZW)(.*)$/mig
```

![screen shot 2014-07-02 at 7 47 31 am](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/122591/3455770/0fc9d8de-01e7-11e4-8a13-535901149a6d.png)

![screen shot 2014-07-02 at 7 47 49 am](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/122591/3455773/1a2a124e-01e7-11e4-9a58-b79ba9f7fee5.png)

data.title: Embed git and detect system git without PATH
data.body:
As of now, installing atom on windows involves cloning the repo and building it from source. This assumes you already have git because the build system uses git to download other parts of the program.

As atom gets an official windows build, however, git may or may not be installed on users machines. A user may also choose between github's Git for Desktop or msysgit. There should be 4 operating modes for atom based on these cases.
1. Integrate with github's Git for Desktop.
2. Detect the user's msysgit installation WITHOUT using the PATH environment variable. First check the default installation location, and if it's not there, prompt the user to supply a path where it's installed. Call the binaries directly from that path.
3. Operate with an embedded version of git. This can be accomplished in the same way atlassian's SourceTree works: Download a portable release of msysgit, and use the binaries from that.
4. Operate without git integration and not complain.

The user should have the option to choose any of the 4 modes in the the settings dialog, and by default, atom should attempt to use them in that order.

This suggestion is mostly based on the windows version of atom, but could apply equally across all platforms with minor modifications. Remove the github desktop option, substitute msysgit for git, etc.

data.title: Build with msysgit on Windows 8.1
data.body: This might work on previous versions of windows, but I've only tested it with windows 8.1. It works fine. I wrote up a document explaining how to build with the steps I took.
